titleStmt.title: Recurrence after Hospitalization for Acute Coronary Syndrome among HIV-Infected and HIV-Uninfected Individuals

affiliation.orgName: Kaiser Permanente San Francisco Medical Center
Kaiser Permanente San Francisco Medical Center
Kaiser Permanente San Leandro Medical Center
Kaiser Permanente Mid-Atlantic Permanente Research Institute

analytic.title: Recurrence after Hospitalization for Acute Coronary Syndrome among HIV-Infected and HIV-Uninfected Individuals

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: CD4 lymphocyte count Recent CD4 cells/μL (HIV-uninfected reference) <200 200-499 ≥500 ACS, acute coronary syndrome
NSTEMI, non-ST elevation myocardial Recent CD4 cells/μL (HIV-uninfected reference) <200 200-499 ≥500 ACS, acute coronary syndrome

p.s: Objectives.-We evaluated the association of HIV infection and immunodeficiency with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) recurrence, and with all-cause mortality as a secondary outcome, after hospitalization for ACS among HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected individuals.

Methods.-We conducted a retrospective cohort study within Kaiser Permanente Northern California of HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected adults discharged after ACS hospitalization (types: ST elevation myocardial infarction [STEMI], non-STEMI, or unstable angina) during 1996-2010.

We compared the outcomes of ACS recurrence and all-cause mortality within three years, both overall by HIV status and stratified by recent CD4 count, with HIV-uninfected individuals as the reference group.
Hazard ratios (HRs) were obtained from Cox regression models with adjustment for age, sex, race/ethnicity, year, ACS type, smoking, and cardiovascular risk factors.

Results.-Among 226 HIV-infected and 86,321 HIV-uninfected individuals with ACS, HIVinfected individuals had a similar risk of ACS recurrence compared with HIV-uninfected individuals (HR 1.08, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.76-1.54).
HIV infection was independently associated with all-cause mortality after ACS hospitalization overall (HR 2.52, 95% CI: 1.81-3.52).
In CD4-stratified models, post-ACS mortality was higher for HIV-infected individuals with CD4 201-499 cells/μL (HR 2.64, 95% CI: 1.66-4.20)
but not those with ≥500 cells/μL (HR 0.67, 95% CI: 0.22-2.08),
compared with HIVuninfected individuals (P trend <0.001).
Antiretroviral therapy use in developed countries has dramatically improved the life expectancy of individuals with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.
(1,2) As a result, medical care for HIV-infected patients is increasingly focused on non-AIDS-related morbidity, with a particularly high burden of cardiovascular disease in this population.
Compared with HIV-uninfected individuals, HIV patients have a 30-80% higher risk of acute coronary syndrome (ACS), including myocardial infarction (MI).

(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)(9) This excess risk may be attributable to chronic inflammation and immunodeficiency in the setting of HIV infection, (7,10) toxicity from antiretroviral medications, (11,12) or the higher prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors among HIV-infected individuals.
(13,14) Although the excess risk of cardiovascular disease among HIV patients has diminished in recent years in our study setting, (15) the impact of HIV infection on ACS prognosis remains unclear.

Prior studies of ACS that included an HIV-uninfected comparison group have found that HIV-infected patients with ACS present at a younger age and, in some cases, with a higher prevalence of traditional coronary risk factors such as smoking and dyslipidemia.
(16)(17)(18)(19)(20)(21) However, few prior studies have had sufficient sample size to account for the role of coronary risk factors in ACS outcomes by HIV status.

Furthermore, because HIV-associated immunodeficiency is linked to risk of primary MIs, HIV patients diagnosed with ACS at low CD4 cell counts may have poorer prognosis, but previous studies have not assessed immunodeficiency as a risk factor for recurrent ACS or mortality.

In this study, we evaluated the association of HIV infection and immunodeficiency with ACS recurrence after hospitalization for ACS among HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected individuals within a large integrated healthcare system, accounting for traditional coronary risk factors.
As a secondary outcome, we also assessed all-cause mortality after hospitalization for ACS among HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected individuals.

We conducted a retrospective cohort study of HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected individuals who were members of Kaiser Permanente (KP) Northern California, a large integrated healthcare system providing comprehensive medical services to 4.1 million members, corresponding to approximately one-third of insured individuals in the surrounding population.

(22) Our study population included adults (≥18 years of age) who were KP members during 1996-2010, and who survived a hospital admission for ACS (i.e., ST elevation myocardial infarction [STEMI], non-STEMI, or unstable angina).

Hospitalizations for ACS were identified using KP's electronic health record (EHR) and defined as a primary discharge diagnosis of acute MI (International Classification of Disease codes, version 9 [ICD-9]: 410x) or unstable angina (ICD-9: 411.x), with MI diagnoses further classified as STEMI (ICD-9: 410.0-410.6,

410.8) or NSTEMI (ICD-9: 410.7, 410.9), using combinations of codes that were previously shown to have a positive predictive value of 97% for any MI, 79% for STEMI, and 91% for NSTEMI in the general population at KP. (23) HIV-infected individuals were identified using a KP HIV registry that includes all known cases of HIV/AIDS since the early 1980s, with HIV-infected status confirmed by review of medical charts or medical center case lists.
Subjects were followed from the first ACS hospitalization at KP until the earliest of ACS recurrence, death, health plan disenrollment, three years after discharge, or December 31, 2010.

For recurrence analyses, the start of follow-up was seven days after discharge to exclude readmissions that were likely associated with the initial ACS event; for mortality analyses, the start of follow-up was ACS hospital discharge.
The institutional review board at KP Northern California approved this study with a waiver of written informed consent.
The primary exposures were HIV infection and immunodeficiency, obtained from the KP HIV registry and CD4 test results, respectively.
The primary outcome was recurrent ACS, and the secondary outcome was death from any cause, both assessed within three years of initial hospitalization for ACS.
Recurrent ACS was ascertained using the same definition as described for primary ACS events.
In addition to KP's EHR, deaths from all causes were ascertained from California death certificates (24) and Social Security Administration datasets.

(25) Other data extracted from the EHR included age; race/ethnicity; health plan enrollment periods; laboratory data (i.e., CD4 T-cell counts, high-density lipoprotein [HDL] and low-density lipoprotein [LDL] cholesterol, and triglycerides); pharmacy data (i.e., ART use, statin use); and clinical diagnoses of smoking/tobacco use (ICD-9: 305.1, V15, V65, 649, internal social history codes) and hypertension (ICD-9: 401.xx).
Diabetes status was ascertained from the KP Northern California diabetes registry.(
We first compared characteristics of HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected ACS cases, using chisquare tests for categorical variables and t-tests for continuous variables.

We then compared ACS recurrence and all-cause mortality within three years after ACS hospitalization using Kaplan-Meier curves and log-rank tests, both overall for HIV status and stratified by age, with HIV-uninfected individuals as the reference group.

Unadjusted and adjusted hazard ratios (HRs) for ACS recurrence and mortality were obtained from Cox regression models comparing HIV-infected with HIV-uninfected individuals, overall and stratified by ACS type and the most recent CD4 count in the six months prior to ACS hospitalization, using likelihood-ratio tests for trends across strata of CD4 count.
We also used adjusted Cox models to identify risk factors for ACS recurrence.

Adjusted models included terms for age, sex, race/ethnicity (white, black, other), ACS hospitalization year, ACS type (STEMI, NSTEMI, unstable angina), smoking (ever/never), LDL (≥160, <160 mg/dl) and HDL cholesterol (<40, ≥40 mg/dl), triglycerides (<150, ≥150 mg/dl), statin use in the year prior to ACS hospitalization (yes/no), hypertension in the year prior to ACS hospitalization (yes/no), and history of diabetes prior to ACS hospitalization (yes/no).

Models in the HIV-infected subset additionally included most recent CD4 cells/μL in the six months prior to first ACS hospitalization (<200, 200-499, ≥500) and current ART use at the time of first ACS hospitalization (none, protease inhibitor-based, protease inhibitor-sparing).
Analyses were conducted in SAS 9.3 (Cary, North Carolina, USA).
Statistical tests were two-sided, and statistical significance was defined as P<0.05.
We identified 229 HIV-infected and 91,281 HIV-uninfected individuals with a hospitalization for ACS, of whom 3 (1.3%) and 4,960 (5.4%) died during hospitalization, respectively.
The study population included the 226 HIV-infected and 86,321 HIVuninfected individuals who survived until hospital discharge (Table 1).
Compared with HIVuninfected individuals, HIV-infected individuals were younger and more were male.

The distribution of ACS type differed by HIV status, with a higher proportion of HIV-infected individuals admitted with STEMI and a lower proportion with unstable angina compared with HIV-uninfected individuals.
A higher proportion of HIV patients had a history of smoking, HDL cholesterol <40 mg/dl, and triglycerides ≥150 mg/dl, whereas a lower proportion had hypertension or diabetes.
LDL cholesterol and statin use were similar by HIV status.

Among the 226 HIV-infected and 86,242 HIV-uninfected subjects with at least seven days of follow-up after ACS hospitalization, the cumulative incidence of ACS recurrence was similar for HIV-infected compared with HIV-uninfected individuals overall (15% vs. 16%, P=0.42) and among those aged <60, 60-64, or ≥65 years (Figure 1).
In unadjusted Cox regression models, ACS recurrence did not differ by HIV status overall or in models stratified by ACS type and CD4 count (Table 2).

After adjustment for demographic and cardiovascular risk factors, HIV-infected individuals had a similar risk of ACS recurrence compared with HIV-uninfected individuals overall (HR 1.08, 95% CI: 0.76-1.54),
and there was no increased risk of ACS recurrence among HIV-infected individuals with STEMI, NSTEMI, or unstable angina.
In adjusted models, ACS recurrence did not differ between HIV-infected individuals with CD4 ≥500 cells/μL (HR 0.82, 95% CI: 0.39-1.73),
those with CD4 201-499 cells/μL (HR 1.14, 95% CI: 0.69-1.90),
or those with CD4 <200 cells/μL (HR 1.42, 95% CI: 0.74-2.72)
compared with HIV-uninfected individuals (P trend = 0.36).
In adjusted models among HIV-infected individuals, only smoking was associated with a higher risk of ACS recurrence (HR 3.52, 95% CI: 1.61-7.72).
Among HIV-uninfected individuals, each additional year of age (HR 1.10, 95% CI: 1.09-1.12),
NSTEMI compared with unstable angina (HR 1.08, 95% CI: 1.03-1.12),
HDL cholesterol <40 mg/dl (HR 1.08, 95% CI: 1.04-1.13),
hypertension (HR 1.13, 95% CI: 1.08-1.18),
and diabetes (HR 1.34, 95% CI: 1.30-1.39)
were associated with an increased risk of ACS recurrence, while increasing year of initial ACS hospitalization was associated with reduced risk of recurrence (HR 0.94, 95% CI: 0.93-0.94).
Sex, smoking, and LDL cholesterol were not associated with ACS recurrence among HIV-uninfected individuals.

Among the 226 HIV-infected and 86,321 HIV-uninfected subjects discharged after an ACS hospitalization, there was no difference in all-cause mortality for HIV-infected compared with HIV-uninfected individuals overall (17% vs. 19%, P=0.43).

However, in age-stratified analysis, mortality was higher for HIV-infected compared with HIV-uninfected individuals who were aged <60 (12% vs. 5.1%, P<0.001) and 60-64 years (19% vs. 9.1%, P=0.022), and numerically but not statistically higher for those aged ≥65 years (39% vs. 28%, P=0.23; Figure 2).

Of the 35 HIV-infected individuals who died in the three years after ACS hospitalization, 34 had a known cause of death; of those, 14 (41%) were attributable to HIV infection, 12 (35%) to cardiovascular disease, and the remaining 8 (24%) to other causes.
In unadjusted Cox regression models, all-cause mortality within three years after ACS hospitalization did not differ by HIV status overall or for any ACS types (Table 3).
In adjusted models, HIV-infected individuals had an over twofold higher risk of death compared with HIV-uninfected individuals (HR 2.52, 95% CI: 1.81-3.52),
with similar results for STEMI, NSTEMI, and unstable angina.
In unadjusted CD4-stratified models, mortality was lower for HIV-infected individuals with CD4 ≥500 cells/μL, and higher for those with CD4 <200 cells/μL, compared with HIV-uninfected individuals.
After adjustment, mortality was similar for HIV-infected individuals with CD4 ≥500 cells/μL (HR 0.67, 95% CI: 0.22-2.08),
but elevated for those with CD4 201-499 cells/μL (HR 2.64, 95% CI: 1.66-4.20)
and those with <200 cells/μL (HR 5.41, 95% CI: 3.14-9.34)
compared with HIVuninfected individuals (P trend <0.001).

In this large observational study of HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected adults hospitalized for ACS within the same healthcare system, HIV infection was not associated with ACS recurrence within three years, even after adjustment for demographic characteristics and cardiovascular risk factors.
We also found no association between CD4 count and ACS recurrence.

HIV infection was independently associated with an over twofold higher risk of all-cause mortality within three years after ACS hospitalization, but HIV-infected individuals with recent CD4 ≥500 cells/μL had a similar prognosis after ACS compared with HIVuninfected individuals.
We found that HIV infection was not associated with an increased risk of ACS recurrence after initial ACS hospitalization.
Prior studies of ACS outcomes that included both HIV patients and an HIV-uninfected comparison group have had mixed results.

Two small matched studies of HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected patients with ACS, conducted in 2003 and 2004, found a higher risk of recurrent events and clinical restenosis in HIV patients, (16,17) while more recent and larger studies found no difference in recurrent events by HIV status (19,20).

Boccara et al. found an increased risk of recurrence in the HIV-infected group within one year; however, this study did not find a difference by HIV status in major adverse cardiac and cerebral events, a composite outcome that included ACS recurrence.
(18) Similarly, Lorgis et al. found an increased risk of hospitalization for heart failure for HIV patients in the first year after acute MI, but no difference in recurrence by HIV status.
(27) Findings on ACS recurrence by HIV status may vary across studies because of heterogeneity in study populations, the distribution of confounders, or analytic approaches.

Findings may also vary over time, as antiretroviral therapy for HIV patients has become more lipidfriendly and the incidence of primary MIs in this population has decreased relative to HIVuninfected individuals.(

15) Finally, similar to findings by Calvo-Sanchez et al., (28) we found that smoking was a strong predictor of ACS recurrence for HIV-infected but not HIVuninfected individuals, highlighting the need for smoking cessation strategies in the HIV patient population.

Immunodeficiency has been linked to incident MIs in HIV-infected individuals, (9,(29)(30)(31) including in our own study population, (7) an association that may reflect the role of chronic inflammation in the development of atherosclerosis.(
10) Here, we build on our prior work by demonstrating that HIV-infected individuals have an increased risk of all-cause mortality but not ACS recurrence at lower CD4 counts.

Indeed, the excess risk of mortality for HIVinfected individuals in our study was specific to those with lower CD4 counts, suggesting that HIV patients with more preserved immune function have similar prognosis after initial ACS hospitalization to HIV-uninfected individuals.
Although 35% of deaths among HIV patients in our study were attributable to cardiovascular causes, we were unable to assess cause of death in the HIV-uninfected patients.
Thus, we could not directly evaluate the relationship between ACS and mortality by HIV status.
There are several limitations to our study.
First, given the large number of cases, we relied on ICD-9 codes to identify ACS diagnoses, and this may have resulted in some misclassification.
The ideal approach would have been prospective adjudication of events, similar to other HIV cohort studies.(32)

However, we used combinations of codes that were previously validated for identification of acute MIs at KP; (23) furthermore, although cardiac enzyme data were not used in our definition of an MI, an MI discharge diagnosis is made at KP only after troponin and/or CK-MB confirmation.
Finally, any misclassification is likely to have been non-differential by HIV status.

Second, because a substantial proportion of deaths in the HIV-infected group were attributable to HIV infection, future studies should assess post-ACS outcomes by HIV status using cause-specific mortality data.
Third, most of the HIV-infected subjects were men, reflecting the epidemiology of the HIV epidemic in California; this may limit the generalizability of our results to women.

Fourth, the relatively small number of HIV-infected individuals resulted in wide confidence intervals in analyses stratified by ACS type and CD4 count, as well as analyses to identify risk factors for recurrence and mortality among HIV patients.

Fifth, we did not include data on postdischarge medications or procedures, such as percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting, which may differ by HIV status; however, given that HIV patients with MI may be treated less aggressively, (33) our results are likely conservative.

Finally, although our analyses included several traditional cardiovascular risk factors, we were not able to assess the role of substance use or specific antiretroviral therapy regimens in risk for ACS recurrence.
Our study also has several strengths.
First, few others have compared ACS outcomes between HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected individuals from the same healthcare system.
Such an approach reduced the likelihood of selection bias and minimized the impact of potential differences by HIV status in access to care.

Second, we expand on the existing literature by investigating the role of CD4 count in ACS outcomes, with results suggesting that immunodeficiency was not associated with ACS recurrence, and that HIV-infected individuals with well-controlled infection have comparable mortality after ACS hospitalization to that of the general population.
Third, our analyses accounted for key confounders, including history of smoking, levels of LDL, HDL, and triglycerides, statin use, hypertension, and diabetes.

Finally, the KP membership mirrors the age, sex, and race/ ethnicity distributions of the California population, (22) and the demographics of HIVinfected members are comparable to those of reported AIDS cases in California.(34)
Thus, our results are likely to be generalizable to the broader insured population.
In summary, our study found a similar three-year risk of ACS recurrence between HIVinfected and HIV-uninfected individuals hospitalized for ACS.

HIV-infected individuals had over double the risk of all-cause mortality within three years after ACS hospitalization, but HIV patients with high CD4 counts were not at increased risk of death compared to HIVuninfected individuals.
Our findings suggest that HIV patients do not have an excess risk of ACS recurrence regardless of their level of immunodeficiency.
Future studies should evaluate the association of HIV infection and immunodeficiency with cardiovascularspecific mortality after ACS.
